title: Penetrating Neck Injury
diagnosis_topic: Zone II neck stab wound with potential vascular and aerodigestive injury
setup_script: A 40-year-old man presents after being stabbed in the right side of his neck. There is active bleeding controlled with direct pressure. He is speaking in a hoarse voice.

dynamic_flow.reply: Patient is alert; airway is patent but intubation equipment should be prepared in case of deterioration.
BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 22/min, SpO2 97%.
Wound located in Zone II anterior to the sternocleidomastoid; no expanding hematoma; tracheal deviation absent.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT angiography of the neck
dynamic_flow.reply: Shows near circumferential laceration of external jugular vein without arterial injury; esophagus and trachea intact.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults vascular surgery and otolaryngology
dynamic_flow.reply: Plan for operative exploration and ligation of injured vein.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays imaging and exploration
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops expanding hematoma with airway compromise.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses selective vs. mandatory exploration
dynamic_flow.reply: Hemodynamically stable zone II injuries can undergo CT angiography to guide management.
Not necessary given CT findings but could be performed if suspicion for esophageal injury exists.
Evaluate vocal cord function postoperatively; consider recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident explains zones of the neck
dynamic_flow.reply: Zone I (clavicles to cricoid), Zone II (cricoid to angle of mandible), Zone III (angle of mandible to base of skull); management differs by zone.
Monitor for bleeding, airway compromise and infection.

critical_decision_points: Airway management and hemodynamic stabilization in penetrating neck injuries
Use of CT angiography for evaluation of zone II injuries
Identification of indications for operative exploration vs. observation
Administration of antibiotics and consultation with subspecialists
